headings: Do you have a head for business and a heart for agriculture?
Earn a Master’s Degree at the Same Time
What Can You Do With an Agribusiness Degree?
Why Study Agribusiness at Angelo State?
paragraphs: Earning your agribusiness degree will combine your interests and prepare you for the many career fields in the business side of the thriving agriculture industry. If you’re interested in banking, economics, sales or management with an emphasis in agriculture, then our agribusiness program could be a perfect fit.

Our agribusiness degree prepares you with a strong foundation in agricultural economics, animal science, accounting, economics and business law. You’ll also gain practical skills at the ASU Ranch and through internships with local agricultural businesses.
You have the option of applying for our integrated program that allows you to earn your B.S. in Agribusiness and yourMaster of Business Administration(MBA) degree in as little as five years.

Our faculty are also industry professionals ready to teach you the latest trends in agribusiness. You’ll also have the chance to work with them on research projects, and our small class sizes mean you get the individual attention you deserve.
ASU Distinguished ScholarshipsOur premier scholarships are awarded based on your academic achievement, and you don’t even have to apply. You are automatically considered once you are admitted to ASU.
General ScholarshipsWe offer over 600 different types of scholarships. You can apply for both our general scholarships and degree-specific scholarships with one application.
Blue and Gold GuaranteeIf you have financial need, you may qualify forfree tuitionto attend Angelo State.

Our diverse program will prepare you for a variety of career fields, including farm and ranch management, agriculture sales, agricultural banking and lending, commodity trading, feedlot management, and agricultural product retail and wholesale.

You’ll spend a lot of time at the Management, Instruction and Research Center, our 6,000-acre ASU Ranch. It’s where we raise cattle, sheep and goats, grow and produce feed, and conduct range and wildlife management activities. You could help with the ranch’s business operations while you learn the different aspects of marketing livestock.

You can improve your knowledge and networking skills by joining one or more of ourstudent organizations, like the Agribusiness Student Association, and trying out for our Agricultural Economics Quiz Bowl Team.

A section of our Plaza Verde residence hall is reserved for incoming freshman ag majors who will live on campus. Living with fellow ag majors will help you adjust to college life, make new friends and get involved.

Take your education to the next level in theASU Honors Program. Through special courses, cultural events, research and community engagement, we’ll help you transform your intellectual and personal talents into marketable skills for your future. You’ll also have the opportunity to participate in prestigious internships, fellowships and other programs to reach your full potential.

OurFreshman Collegeis a one-stop resource for programs and services that help you transition into college life, improve your communication skills, and engage in active learning. You can also get academic help in theMath LabandWriting Center, receive peer mentoring and tutoring throughSupplemental Instruction, or set up onlinetutoringsessions.
If you want to go fast, go alone. But if you want to go far, go together.

Corey Owens, Class of 2005 and 2007

“The Ag Department at ASU offers hands-on learning experiences that cannot be duplicated in a classroom alone.”

Corey Owens, Class of 2005 and 2007

“The MIR Center/University Ranch is where the rubber meets the road for an Ag major. Here, you get to apply the knowledge learned in the classroom in a real-world setting.”

Corey Owens, Class of 2005 and 2007

“In the Ag Department, there’s a lot more hands-on learning than most universities because of the smaller class sizes. You’re actually getting to interact and do things with the animals, do things on the ranch.”

Trevor Schwartz, Agribusiness

“What truly sets the ASU Ag Department apart is the opportunities for internships and our ability to place students in successful careers when they graduate.”

Corey Owens, Class of 2005 and 2007
